description.plain:
Slowdive are an English shoegaze/dream pop band that formed in Reading, Berkshire in 1989. The band consists of Rachel Goswell on vocals and guitar, Simon Scott on drums, Neil Halstead on vocals and guitar, Nick Chaplin on bass and Christian Savill on guitar. Several other drummers also briefly played with the band, including Adrian Sell, Neil Carter and Ian McCutcheon. Halstead is the band’s primary songwriter.

Soon after the release of Pygmalion, some of the members left the band and the remaining members renamed the band Mojave 3. Slowdive reunited in 2014, soon releasing a self-titled album.

Several other drummers also briefly played with the band, including Adrian Sell, Neil Carter and Ian McCutcheon. Halstead is the band’s primary songwriter.

Soon after the release of Pygmalion, some of the members left the band and the remaining members renamed the band Mojave 3. Slowdive reunited in 2014, soon releasing a self-titled album.

songs.title: 40 Days

description.plain:
Seeking seclusion after his breakup with Rachel Goswell, Neil Halstead left on a 2 week trip to a Welsh cottage, where he recorded this song.

It hadn’t been long since i and Rachel split up, so i was kinda miserable about that, and i was miserable to be in this little cottage in the middle of nowhere.“, – he says. "It was about being miserable. A lot of Slowdive’s stuff was about atmospheres, and so possibly in a sort of slightly teenagy way it was about creating cinematic moments. So i guess lyrics would try to look into it. It’s like when you watch a film it could remind you of really sweet moments and you kinda look into that as a feeling, and i think sometimes that sort of stuff carry over into songs.

— Neil, in Pitchfork’s Classic Slowdive episode

The drums are very loose, it kinda bounced a bit more, it skipped and then it’s kind of a new thing to the Slowdive’s sound. It gave Neil, Rachel, and Christian more freedom to sort of play with a sound in a new way.

— Simon Scott, Slowdive drummer

We were looking for a more sparkly and in some ways poppier feel to certain aspects of it, we didn`t want to make an entire pop record, but we wanted to have more light and shade, and more sort of feel to it.

— Christian Savill, Slowdive guitarist

songs.title: Altogether

description.plain:
“Altogether” is the eighth track of Slowdive’s second studio album Souvlaki.

The song creates a sleepy mood with both its lyricism and its atmosphere – in the context of the band, the lyrics are probably highlighting a past romantic moment between Neil Halstead and Rachel Goswell that they shared before they broke up (the majority of the album is like this).

songs.title: Avalyn I

description.plain:
‘Avalyn I’ is the second track off of the band’s first compliation album, Blue Day.

A light guitar starts off the song, as if one had just fallen asleep. The song picks up to the second when theyj ust entered a dream full of overwhelming emotions, with drums beating to the speed of a heart, and eventually, the dreamer realizes that they are in a dream.

Despite acknowledging they’re in a dream, the dreamer is not in control and is left alone to a dream of flashing emotions, with no one to be there.

songs.title: Dagger

description.plain:
The final song on Souvlaki, “Dagger” was written during a retreat to a Welsh cottage by Neil Halstead in the summer of 1992. It is about a “fucked up relationship”, likely the one Neil and Rachel shared during the early days of the band.

The song has an acoustic sound, which is pretty unique in Slowdive’s discography, but similar to the dream-folk style of Mojave 3, the band formed by Neil Halstead, Rachel Goswell, and Ian McCutcheon after Slowdive’s disbandment.

songs.title: Falling Ashes

description.plain: “Falling Ashes”, the closing track off Slowdive’s self-titled album, is the clearest break with their past and perhaps the biggest clue of where they’re headed next. It’s a sparse, piano led composition, co-written by Neil Halsted and Simon Scott. Scott describes it as the type of song they can write now due to the advances in technology.

songs.title: Machine Gun

description.plain: The capital of Sheba was the city of Ma'rib. Nearby was a great dam, which provided enough water to make Sheba an agricultural nation, as well as a land of beautiful gardens. It was a fertile oasis in the desert. There is evidence that this dam burst, and the devastation caused by the ensuing flood, coupled with the loss of water for agriculture, may have led to the demise of several Sabaean cities which no longer exist today.

description.plain: ‘Melon Yellow’ is the ninth track of Slowdive’s second studio album ‘Souvlaki’. It has been speculated that the song is about limerence – a state of mind stemming from an obsessive romantic attraction to another person and a desire to be with this person and get one’s feelings reciprocated.

songs.title: Sing

description.plain: Early demos for the album were influenced by David Bowie’s Low, among other albums. Slowdive asked Brian Eno to produce the album but he declined, however, he agreed to do a couple of days of recording with Neil Halstead, and out of these sessions came the tracks “Sing” and “Here She Comes”. Eno provides keyboards and treatments on both tracks, ending up with co-writing “Sing” with Neil. Following these sessions Neil began to take greater influence from ambient music and has cited Aphex Twin, dub music, and early drum and bass as influences for the track “Souvlaki Space Station”.

songs.title: Souvlaki Space Station

description.plain: Early demos for the album were influenced by David Bowie’s Low, among other albums. Low was produced by Brian Eno and Slowdive asked him to produce their album. He declined, however, he agreed to do a couple of days of recording with Halstead, and out of these sessions came the tracks “Sing” and “Here She Comes”. Eno provides keyboards and treatments on both tracks. Following these sessions Halstead began to take greater influence from ambient music and has cited Aphex Twin, dub music, and early drum and bass as influences for the track “Souvlaki Space Station”.

songs.title: Untitled No. 3

description.plain:
“Stars” is a dream pop ballad that could have several interpretations.

It’s likely the lyrics are about a father or a mother who’s happy and hopeful because their daughter found the love of her life.

Though, if seen from a teenage perspective, maybe is a resignation from a person who was in love with this girl after realizing she found someone better.

album.full_title: Just for a Day by Slowdive
album.name: Just for a Day

songs.lyrics:
[Verse 1]
Watch the waves so far away
They're washing 'cross the paths that I have made
Leaving all my sins, I turn away
Like soaring birds, I watch my sorrows play

[Chorus]
Don't you know, I've left and gone away
You're knocking on the door I closed today
And everything looks brighter
The waves, they just soothe my pain away

[Verse 2]
It felt so good to see the sun
I'll choose my time before I choose the one
Floating 'cross the waves, the silence runs
My thoughts can go, but now, my sorrow's done

[Chorus]
Don't you know, I've left and gone away
You're knocking on the door I closed today
And everything looks brighter
The waves they just soothe my pain away1EmbedShare URLCopyEmbedCopy

songs.full_title: When the Sun Hits by Slowdive
songs.title: When the Sun Hits

description.plain: According to Slowdive fans, “When The Sun Hits” is one of their finest songs. Surprisingly, it was almost left off Souvlaki. Apparently Christian and Nick “fought like hell” to get the song in the album, according to John Kupchik.
